revision.text:
[[Image:GAMALogo.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Logo of the Game Manufacturers Association.]] The '''Game Manufacturers Association''' ('''GAMA''') is a [[non-profit]] [[trade association]] based in [[Columbus, Ohio]], dedicated to the advancement of the non-electronic social [[game]]s [[industry]] - Board/Tabletop Games, Miniatures Games, Card Games, Collectable/Tradeable Card Games, Role-Playing Games, and Live-Action Role Playing Games. Its members are game manufacturers, retailers, distributors, suppliers, conventions, clubs, and independent professionals related to the games industry.
The association was formed in 1977 to protect the interests of the [[Origins Game Fair]], and was incorporated as a non-profit venture in 1982.
GAMA organizes two shows each year, the GAMA Trade Show (GTS) in [[Reno, Nevada]] - a professional trade show aimed at game retailers, and the [[Origins Game Fair]] in [[Columbus, Ohio]] - a 15,000 person consumer show that is aimed at the game-playing public.
GAMA has a number of programs designed to advance hobby games as a business. The Games in Education program strives to teach educators how they can use games in their curricula. The retailer mentoring program is aimed at helping new game stores become successful businesses. The Industry Watch Committee helps stores and publishers deal with negative press about games. In all they do, they endeavor to strengthen the business of publishing and selling games.
In 2006 GAMA began the Games to Troops program, working with the [[Morale, Welfare and Recreation|MWR]] offices of all four US military service branches to establish a permanent games library at every MWR station on the US front lines. The social games industry has since sent over a quarter of a million dollars in games to the US troops through this program.
== External links == * http://www.gama.org/ * http://www.originsgamefair.com/
[[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Ohio]] [[Category:Game manufacturers]] [[Category:1977 establishments in Ohio]] [[Category:Economy of Columbus, Ohio]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1977]]

'''Jean Pierre Ginnett''' (died 1861) founded the Ginnett circus dynasty. His son, John Frederick Ginnett (1825 in [[London]] – 1892) and three grandsons Claude (b. [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]]), Frederick Emile (b. [[Sheffield]]) and Albert (b. [[Southampton]]) followed him.
Jean Pierre Ginnett is buried in [[Kensal Green Cemetery]]. John Frederick Ginnett is buried in the family vault in [[Cemeteries and crematoria in Brighton and Hove#Woodvale_Cemetery_and_Crematorium|Woodvale Cemetery and Crematorium]] in [[Brighton]].
==See also== *[[Samuel Lockhart]], elephant trainer at Ginnett's Circus
==External links== * https://web.archive.org/web/20060616102509/http://users.nwon.com/pauline/Duffy.html * https://web.archive.org/web/20050911125933/http://users.nwon.com/pauline/1871.html

revision.text:
On '''Kids’ Night on Broadway''', kids age 6-18 get to see a participating [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] show for free when accompanied by a full-paying adult as well as dining deals and more. Kids’ Night on Broadway takes place each winter in [[New York City]], as well as all year round in cities across the U.S.<ref name="Kids Night on Broadway">{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.broadwayleague.com/index.php?url_identifier=kids-night-on-broadway-1|title=Kids' Night on Broadway|work=|accessdate=2010-07-07|date=}}</ref>
[[File:Kids' Night on Broadway Logo.jpg|thumb|right|600px|Logo for Kids' Night on Broadway.]]
__TOC__
== History == '''Kids’ Night on Broadway (KNOB)''' is a program of [[The Broadway League]], the national trade association for the [[Broadway theatre]] industry. Designed to introduce young people to the magic of live theatre and make Broadway accessible to a new generation of theatergoers, Kids’ Night on Broadway has welcomed young people to Broadway shows in New York and on tour across the U.S. since the program was created in 1996 by [[The Broadway League]] and the [[Theatre Development Fund]].<ref name="Kids Night on Broadway"/>
As the League’s signature national audience development program, Kids’ Night on Broadway offers children age’s 6-18 free admission to participating shows when accompanied by a full-paying adult. In addition, KNOB offers family-friendly restaurant and parking discounts. Since its inception in 1996 to KNOB 2012, over 175,000 kids have participated with over 250,000 tickets sold. Kids’ Night on Broadway takes place in other cities across the county, all year long.<ref name="Kids Night on Broadway"/>
== Event Details == * Free tickets to young people age 6-18 who attend a [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] show with a paying adult.<ref name="nytix">{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.nytix.com/Broadway/DiscountBroadwayTickets/kidsnight.html|title=Kids' Night on Broadway Discount Broadway Tickets|work=|accessdate=2010-07-07|date=}}</ref> *Area restaurant and parking discounts in [[New York City]].<ref name="nytix"/> *Kids go free at pre-theatre educational event, parties, and activities such as Broadway dance lessons, theatrical make-up stations, Autograph Alley with Broadway performers, and participation in the [[Natural Resources Defense Council|Broadway Green Alliance's]] bottle cap collection drive.<ref name="nytix"/><ref name="theatermania">{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.theatermania.com/new-york-city-theater/news/02-2012/nick-jonas-to-host-pre-theater-party-for-kids-nigh_49672.html|title=Theatermania - Nick Jonas to Host Pre-Theater Party for Kids' Night on Broadway|work=|accessdate=2010-07-07|date=}}</ref> *Kids’ Night on Broadway Activity Guide, provided by [[The New York Times]].<ref name="nytix"/>
== Sponsors == [[The New York Times]] is the presenting sponsor of Kids’ Night on Broadway, a program of [[The Broadway League]]. In 2012, [[Madame Tussauds]] New York was also an official sponsor. Official media partners were WABC-TV, Z100, and 103.5 KTU.<ref name="Kids Night on Broadway"/>
As 2012’s cause-related component, Kids' Night on Broadway saluted [[Givenik]], the only place on the web to get [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] tickets and have 5% donated to the charity of your choice.<ref name="Kids Night on Broadway"/>
== Past Events == Since its inception in 1996, Kids’ Night on Broadway has attracted thousands of kids to the program that not only offers discount tickets to [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] shows, but also allows young theatergoers the opportunity to experience some of the behind the scenes magic of the theatre.<ref name="NY Times">{{cite web|author=|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/10/17/theater/broadway-s-gift-for-children.html|title=New York Times - Broadway's Gift for Children|work=|accessdate=2010-07-07|date=}}</ref><ref name="playbill">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/48233-Tix-for-Jan-25-Kids-Night-On-Broadway-On-Sale-Oct-17 |title=Playbill - Tickets for January 25 Kids' Night on Broadway On Sale October 17 |work= |accessdate=2010-07-07 |date= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140219024854/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/48233-Tix-for-Jan-25-Kids-Night-On-Broadway-On-Sale-Oct-17 |archivedate=2014-02-19 |df= }}</ref>
In 2000, Kids’ Night on Broadway expanded from not only one night, but to two nights of live theatre experience for kids, ages 6 to 18, across the country.<ref name="NY Times Footlights">{{cite web|author=|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/10/14/theater/footlights.html|title=New York Times - Footlights|work=|accessdate=2010-07-07|date=}}</ref> KNOB also served as an anchor event for "Rising Stars Live Broadway Talent Contest," a talent contest where entrants won tickets to Broadway shows, signed posters, CDs, and more as well as be judged by professional agents, and the "Kids’ Fan Fair," which offered backstage activities including dance lessons, face painting, makeup design, and trying on Broadway costumes before the KNOB theatre performances.<ref name="playbill"/>
2007’s KNOB events were sponsored by [[Autism Speaks]]. Fear-mongering about autism and [[Autism Speaks]] were printed on Kids' Night materials, on its websites, and at fanfest events at [[Madame Tussauds]]. [[Julie Andrews]] and daughter [[Emma Walton Hamilton]] acted as Kid’s Night on Broadway National Ambassadors for the event held at Madame Tussauds.<ref name="Autism Speaks">{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.autismspeaks.org/news/news-item/kids-night-broadway-spotlight-autism|title=Autism Speaks News|work=|accessdate=2010-07-07|date=}}</ref>
[[Rosie O'Donnell]] served as 2008’s Kids’ Night on Broadway National Ambassador. The event, sponsored by [[Madame Tussauds]] New York and [[The New York Times]], included an educational component and pre-theatre events in addition to the discounted tickets. A party held at Madame Tussauds kicked off the event. Ms. O’Donnell served as the National Ambassador in 2009, as well.<ref name="Theatermania Rosie ODonnell Article">{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.theatermania.com/new-york-city-theater/news/11-2007/rosie-odonnell-to-head-kids-night-on-broadway_11984.html|title=Theatermania - Rosie O'Donnell to Head Kids' Night on Broadway|work=|accessdate=2010-07-07|date=}}</ref>
In 2010, [[Adam Riegler]], who played Pugsley in ''The Addams Family'' musical, acted as KNOB National Ambassador for a special Kids’ Night on Broadway Halloween Edition. This special edition of Kids’ Night saluted [[UNICEF]] and the 60th anniversary of its Trick-or-Treat for UNICEF program.<ref name="KNOB Halloween Press Release">{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.broadwayleague.com/index.php?url_identifier=press-releases&news=announcing-kids-night-on-broadway-halloween&type=news|title=Kids' Night on Broadway Special Halloween Edition Press Release|work=|accessdate=2010-07-30|date=}}</ref>
In [[New York City]], KNOB took place on February 5–9, 2012. Participants experienced the behind-the-scenes magic of Broadway at a pre-theatre party at Madame Tussauds.<ref name="Madame Tussauds">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.madametussauds.com/NewYork/NewsAndEvents/KNOB/default.aspx |title=Madame Tussauds Kids' Night on Broadway Event News |work= |accessdate=2010-07-30 |date= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100125094928/http://www.madametussauds.com/NewYork/NewsAndEvents/KNOB/default.aspx |archivedate=2010-01-25 |df= }}</ref> Plus, Kids’ got to eat for less thanks to special family discounts at [[Times Square]] area restaurants.<ref name="BroadwayWorld Nick Jonas">{{cite web|author=|url=http://broadwayworld.com/article/Nick-Jonas-to-Host-2012-KIDS-NIGHT-ON-BROADWAY-25-9-20120204|title=BroadwayWorld - Nick Jonas to Host Kids' Night on Broadway 2012|work=|accessdate=2010-07-30|date=}}</ref><ref name="BroadwayWorld Shows Taking Part">{{cite web|author=|url=http://broadwayworld.com/article/GODSPELL-SISTER-ACT-et-al-to-Take-Part-in-2011-Kids-Night-on-Broadway-20111026|title=BroadwayWorld - Godspell, Sister Act, et al To Take Part in 2011 Kids' Night on Broadway|work=|accessdate=2010-07-30|date=}}</ref><ref name="Playbill Pre Theatre Party">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/159397-Nick-Jonas-Hosts-Pre-Theatre-Party-For-Kids-Night-on-Broadway-Feb-7 |title=Playbill - Nick Jonas Hosts Pre-Theatre Party for Kids' Night on Broadway |work= |accessdate=2010-07-30 |date= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208082530/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/159397-Nick-Jonas-Hosts-Pre-Theatre-Party-For-Kids-Night-on-Broadway-Feb-7 |archivedate=2012-02-08 |df= }}</ref>
The 2012 National Ambassador was [[Nick Jonas]], then appearing as J. Pierrepont Finch in ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying.'' Presented by [[The New York Times]].<ref name="Madame Tussauds"/><ref name="Playbill Pre Theatre Party"/> A free fan festival drew an estimated 3,000 kids and their parents to [[Madame Tussauds]] in New York.<ref name="BroadwayWorld Nick Jonas"/><ref name="BroadwayWorld Shows Taking Part"/><ref name="Playbill Pre Theatre Party"/>
Other past ambassadors include [[Kelly Ripa]], [[Sarah Jessica Parker]], and [[John Lithgow]]. Kids' Night in Broadway has been hosted at a number of venues including [[Macy's]], [[Toys “R” Us]], [[Madame Tussauds]], [[Bowlmor Lanes]], and [[Roseland Ballroom]].<ref>{{cite web|first1=Patrick|last1=Healy|url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/10/25/broadway-recruits-nick-jonas-to-boost-kids-night-attendance/|title=Artsbeat - Broadway Recruits Nick Jonas to Boost Kids' Night Attendance|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2010-07-30|date=2011-10-25}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox television | | show_name = King of Kensington | image = | caption = | runtime = 30 minutes | creator = [[Perry Rosemond]] | starring = [[Al Waxman]]
[[Fiona Reid]]
Helene Winston
[[Rosemary Radcliffe]]
[[Jayne Eastwood]] | country = Canada | network = [[CBC Television]] | first_aired = September 25, 1975 | last_aired = March 13, 1980 |num_seasons = 5 | num_episodes = 111 |}} '''''King of Kensington''''' is a [[Television in Canada|Canadian]] television [[sitcom]] which aired on [[CBC Television]] from 1975 to 1980. ==Synopsis== [[Al Waxman]] starred as Larry King, a convenience store owner in [[Toronto]]'s [[Kensington Market]] who was known for helping friends and neighbours solve problems. His multicultural group of friends consisted of Nestor Best ([[Ardon Bess]]), Max (John J. Dee), and Tony "Duke" Zarro (Bob Vinci), who hung around regularly to the perennial disapproval of King's mother Gladys (Helene Winston). For the first three seasons, [[Fiona Reid]] played his wife Cathy. At the end of the third season, Reid decided to leave the series, so Larry and Cathy divorced. Larry then pursued other relationships, most notably with Gwen Twining ([[Jayne Eastwood]]) in the final season. ==Production== The show was created by [[Perry Rosemond]], who also produced the first season. Other producers included [[Jack Humphrey (producer)|Jack Humphrey]] (1976–1980) and Joe Partington (1978–1980). The series featured many Canadian actors as guest stars, including [[Mike Myers]], [[John Candy]], [[Eugene Levy]], [[Dave Thomas (actor)|Dave Thomas]], [[Jeff Wincott]] and [[Mark Humphrey (actor)|Mark Humphrey]]. The show was popular with viewers; prior to the start of the fourth season, one of the producers noted the show drew 1.5 to 1.8 million viewers weekly.{{cite web |url= https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Ajc0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=NfUIAAAAIBAJ&pg=1052,1749516&dq=fiona-reid&hl=en |title=King to be bachelor|work= Ottawa Citizen |date=1978-01-25|accessdate=9 April 2011}} The show's gentle but politically conscious humour is seen by some critics as a Canadian version of the topical [[Norman Lear]] sitcoms of the 1970s, such as ''[[All in the Family]]'' and ''[[Maude (TV series)|Maude]]''. The series was [[television syndication|syndicated]] to some [[United States|American]] stations during the height of its popularity, including [[WTTG]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] After ''King of Kensington'' ended in 1980, many of the producers went on to create the new CBC sitcom ''[[Hangin' In]]'', while head writer [[Louis Del Grande]] went on to create and star in ''[[Seeing Things (TV series)|Seeing Things]]'', and Waxman was cast in the [[United States|American]] series ''[[Cagney & Lacey]]''. ==Cast== *[[Al Waxman]] as Larry King *Helene Winston as Gladys King *[[Fiona Reid]] as Cathy King (1975–1978) *[[Ardon Bess]] as Nestor Best (1975–1978) *Bob Vinci as Tony "Duke" Zarro (1975–1978) *John J. Dee as Max (1975–1978) *[[Jayne Eastwood]] as Gwen Twining (1978–1980) *Peter Boretski as Jack Soble (1978–1980) *[[Robert Haley]] as Ron Bacon (1978–1980) *[[Rosemary Radcliffe]] as Tina (1978–1980) *Linda Rennhofer as Dorothy (1978–1980) ==Episode list== ===Season 1 (1975–76)=== {| class=wikitable style="text-align:center; background:#EFFFEA" ! Airdate |- | 1 || 66 || align="left"|King's First Date || Sep-28-1978 |- | 2 || 67 || align="left"|Summer of '56 || Oct-05-1978 |- | 3 || 68 || align="left"|School Daze || Oct-12-1978 |- | 4 || 69 || align="left"|The Invitation || Oct-19-1978 |- | 5 || 70 || align="left"|Words and Music || Oct-26-1978 |- | 6 || 71 || align="left"|Carol's Arrival || Nov-02-1978 |- | 7 || 72 || align="left"|Double Standard || Nov-09-1978 |- | 8 || 73 || align="left"|The Pursesnatcher || Nov-16-1978 |- | 9 || 74 || align="left"|Third Party || Dec-07-1978 |- | 10 || 75 || align="left"|Big Brother || Dec-14-1978 |- | 11 || 76 || align="left"|A Xmas Story || Dec-21-1978 |- | 12 || 77 || align="left"|The Houseguest || Dec-28-1978 |- | 13 || 78 || align="left"|With This Ring || Jan-04-1979 |- | 14 || 79 || align="left"|Guido's Job || Jan-11-1979 |- | 15 || 80 || align="left"|Over the Hill || Jan-18-1979 |- | 16 || 81 || align="left"|Dear Aunt Martha || Jan-25-1979 |- | 17 || 82 || align="left"|The Best Man || Feb-01-1979 |- | 18 || 83 || align="left"|Hockey Night in Kensington || Feb-15-1979 |- | 19 || 84 || align="left"|True Confessions || Feb-22-1979 |- | 20 || 85 || align="left"|Mr. King Goes to Ottawa || Mar-08-1979 |- | 21 || 86 || align="left"|White Lace Gloves || Mar-15-1979 |- | 22 || 87 || align="left"|The Fishing Trip || Mar-22-1979 |- | 23 || 88 || align="left"|Cyrano de Kensington || Mar-29-1979 |} ===Season 5 (1979–80)=== {| class=wikitable style="text-align:center; background:#EFFFEA" ! Ep ! № ! Title ! Airdate |- | 1 || 89 || align="left"|King's Brave New World || Sep-13-1979 |- | 2 || 90 || align="left"|Diabolical Plots || Sep-20-1979 |- | 3 || 91 || align="left"|Life Begins at Forty || Sep-27-1979 |- | 4 || 92 || align="left"|The Hat Trick || Oct-04-1979 |- | 5 || 93 || align="left"|Home Is Where the Heartburn Is || Oct-11-1979 |- | 6 || 94 || align="left"|The Rivals || Oct-25-1979 |- | 7 || 95 || align="left"|Born to Boogie || Nov-01-1979 |- | 8 || 96 || align="left"|The Double Date || Nov-08-1979 |- | 9 || 97 || align="left"|Masters and Johnson and King || Nov-15-1979 |- | 10 || 98 || align="left"|The Bet || Nov-22-1979 |- | 11 || 99 || align="left"|Pawn to King Four || Nov-29-1979 |- | 12 || 100 || align="left"|Down But Not Out || Dec-06-1979 |- | 13 || 101 || align="left"|Catch 23 || Dec-20-1979 |- | 14 || 102 || align="left"|The Total Woman || Jan-03-1980 |- | 15 || 103 || align="left"|Look Ma, No Cavities || Jan-10-1980 |- | 16 || 104 || align="left"|Sign of the Bull || Jan-17-1980 |- | 17 || 105 || align="left"|The Spirit of Joy || Jan-24-1980 |- | 18 || 106 || align="left"|Good News, Bad News || Jan-31-1980 |- | 19 || 107 || align="left"|War and Peace || Feb-07-1980 |- | 20 || 108 || align="left"|Counter Attack || Feb-21-1980 |- | 21 || 109 || align="left"|Green Eyed Monster || Feb-28-1980 |- | 22 || 110 || align="left"|Purple Passion || Mar-06-1980 |- | 23 || 111 || align="left"|Movin' On || Mar-13-1980 |} ==Tributes== In the ''[[Second City Television|SCTV]]'' episode "CCCP1-Russian television", one of the fake TV programs infiltrating the network is ''Hey Giorgiy'', about "everyone's favorite Cossack", intended as a Russian knockoff of ''King of Kensington''. In the first episode of the 1990s television series ''[[Twitch City]]'', also set in Kensington, the character Nathan (played by [[Daniel MacIvor]]) was sent to prison for killing a homeless man with a can of cat food. The producers of ''Twitch City'' cast Al Waxman in the role of the murder victim, as a symbolic wink to ''King of Kensington'', although they claimed that they did not intend for the character to be seen as Larry King himself."Twitch City a weird look at television addiction; Former King of Kensington gets whacked tonight". ''[[Edmonton Journal]]'', January 19, 1988. In the late 1990s, ''[[This Hour Has 22 Minutes]]'' featured a sketch detailing the making of a film version of ''King of Kensington.'' In the sketch, director [[Atom Egoyan]] (played by [[Greg Thomey]]), re-imagines the series as a surreal crime thriller, with Larry King as a serial killer instead of a convenience store owner. Following Waxman's death on January 18, 2001, a memorial to him was erected in Kensington Market. In one episode of the Canadian comedy program ''[[Puppets Who Kill]]'', the character Bill steals Al Waxman's preserved brain from CBC headquarters. ==DVD release== On November 13, 2007, Morningstar Entertainment released ''King of Kensington – Season One'' on [[DVD]] in Region 1.{{cite web |url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/King-Kensington-Season-1/8344 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-05-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019092321/http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/King-Kensington-Season-1/8344 |archivedate=2012-10-19 |df= }} ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == {{portal|Television in Canada}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101211143941/http://contentfilm.com/common/file.php/pg/localhost74/contentfilm.com/binaries/1914/King%20of%20Kensington.pdf ''King of Kensington'' Cast Photo and Synopsis] * [http://www.tvarchive.ca/database/17483/king_of_kensington/episode_guide/ ''King of Kensington'' Episode Guide at TV Archive Site] * {{IMDb title|0072529|King of Kensington}} [[Category:1975 Canadian television series debuts]] [[Category:1980 Canadian television series endings]] [[Category:1970s Canadian sitcoms]] [[Category:1980s Canadian sitcoms]] [[Category:CBC Television shows]] [[Category:Jewish comedy and humor]] [[Category:Jewish-related television programs]] [[Category:Television shows set in Toronto]] [[Category:Kensington Market]] [[Category:Television series produced in Toronto]]

revision.text:
[[File:Michel Glotz.JPG|thumb|<center>Michel Glotz</center>]]
'''Michel Glotz''' (1 February 1931 – 15 February 2010) was a French classical music [[record producer]] and [[impresario]].
== Life == Glotz was a student of [[Marguerite Long]] and accomplice of [[Francis Poulenc]] with whom he had a long correspondence. [[Artistic director]] of several record companies ([[EMI Group|EMI]], [[Deutsche Grammophon]], [[RCA Victor]], [[Philips]], [[Sony]]), he had more than a thousand discs recorded, including a hundred operas. In this capacity, he obtained several [[Grammy Awards]] in Hollywood including [[Beethoven]]'s nine symphonies by [[Herbert von Karajan]] with the [[Berlin Philharmonic]] in 1978, or the "most beautiful opera of the year" award for Bizet's ''[[Carmen]]'' in 1984. In 1966, he and his collaborator Thérèse Darras founded a concert agency called Musicaglotz. He then turned his attention to the careers of legendary artists such as [[Maria Callas]], [[Herbert von Karajan]], [[Alain Lombard]], [[Alexis Weissenberg]]. Glotz received the insignia of [[Ordre des Arts et des Lettres|officier des Arts et Lettres]], and [[chevalier de la Légion d'honneur]] en 2007.
He died of a heart attack in 2010 at age 79.
== Artists represented == * Conductors: [[Serge Baudo]], [[Sergiu Comissiona]], [[James Conlon]], [[Christoph Eschenbach]], [[Patrick Fournillier]], [[James Judd]], [[Alain Lombard]], [[Jesus Lopez Cobos]], [[Kurt Masur]], [[Seiji Ozawa]], [[Georges Prêtre]], [[Gennady Rozhdestvensky]], [[Thomas Sanderling]], [[Michel Tabachnik]], [[Michael Tilson Thomas]] * Pianists: [[Philippe Bianconi]], [[Jean-Philippe Collard]], [[Kun-Woo Paik]], [[Ivo Pogorelich]], [[Viktoria Postnikova]], [[François Weigel]], [[Alexis Weissenberg]] * Violinists: [[Pierre Amoyal]], [[Anne-Sophie Mutter]], [[Tedi Papavrami]] * Cellists: [[Natalia Gutman]], [[Gary Hoffman (cellist)|Gary Hoffman]], [[Yo-Yo Ma]], [[Mstislav Rostropovich]] * Sopranos: [[Montserrat Caballé]], [[Maria Callas]], [[Renée Fleming]], [[Mirella Freni]], [[Inva Mula]], [[Leontyne Price]], [[Katia Ricciarelli]], [[Anna Tomowa-Sintow]], [[Shirley Verrett]] * Mezzo-sopranos: [[Agnes Baltsa]], [[Jane Berbié]], [[Teresa Berganza]], [[Susan Graham]], [[Sophie Koch]], [[Christa Ludwig]], [[Marie-Ange Todorovitch]] * Tenors: [[José Carreras]], [[Laurence Dale]], [[Placido Domingo]], [[Chris Merritt]], [[Kenneth Riegel]], [[Michel Sénéchal]] * Baritones: [[Gabriel Bacquier]], [[Jean-Luc Chaignaud]], [[Manfred Hemm]], [[Nicolas Rivenq]], [[Bryn Terfel]] * Basses: [[Paata Burchuladze]], Jean-Philippe Courtis, [[Ferruccio Furlanetto]], [[Nicolai Ghiaurov]], [[Tom Krause]]
== Recordings == * Franck's [[Symphony in D minor (Franck)|Symphony in D minor]] - [[Orchestre de Paris]], [[Herbert von Karajan]] conductor, recorded in Paris, [[Salle Wagram]], for EMI (077776474724), November 1969 * Tchaikovski's Piano Concerto n°1 op.23 - [[Alexis Weissenberg]], piano, Orchestre de Paris, Herbert von Karajan conductor, recorded in Paris, Salle Wagram, for EMI (3C06302044), February 1970 * Brahms's Ouverture tragique op.81, [[Berlin Philharmonic]], Herbert von Karajan conductor, recorded in the Jesus-Christus church of Berlin for EMI, September 1970 * Bruckner's Symphony n°4 (''Romantic''), Berlin Philharmonic, Herbert von Karajan conductor, recorded in the Jesus-Christus church of Berlin for EMI, September 1970 * Bruckner's Symphony n°7, Berlin Philharmonic, Herbert von Karajan conductor, recorded in the Jesus-Christus church of Berlin for EMI, September 1970 * Mozart's Symphony n°38 KV504, Berlin Philharmonic, Herbert von Karajan conductor, recorded at the Jesus-Christus church of Berlin for EMI, September 1970 * Mozart' Symphony n°39 KV543, Berlin Philharmonic, Herbert von Karajan conductor, recorded at the Jesus-Christus church of Berlin for EMI, September 1970 * Mozart's Symphony n°40 KV550, Berlin Philharmonic, Herbert von Karajan conductor, recorded at the Jesus-Christus church of Berlin for EMI, September 1970 * Mozart' Symphony n°41 KV551, Berlin Philharmonic, Herbert von Karajan conductor, recorded at the Jesus-Christus church of Berlin for EMI, September 1970 * Ravel's ''[[Boléro]]'' - Orchestre de Paris, Herbert von Karajan conductor, recorded in Paris, Salle Wagram, for EMI (724356945920), June 1971 * Ravel's ''[[Miroirs|Alborada del gracioso]]'' - Orchestre de Paris, Herbert von Karajan conductor, recorded in Paris, Salle Wagram, for EMI, June 1971 * Ravel's ''[[La Valse]]'' - Orchestre de Paris, Herbert von Karajan conductor, recorded in Paris, Salle Wagram for EMI, June 1971 * [[Joseph Haydn]]: Symphony n°83 - Berlin Philharmonic, Herbert von Karajan conductor, recorded at the French church of Saint-Maurice for EMI, August 1971 * Haydn: Symphony n°101 - {{Infobox National Olympic Committee | title = National Sports Committee of Indonesia
''Komite Olahraga Nasional Indonesia'' | logo = National Sports Committee of Indonesia (KONI) logo.svg | size = 150px | country = Indonesia | code = INA | created = 1946 | recognized = 1952 | association = OCA | headquarters = [[Jakarta]], [[Indonesia]] | president = Tono Suratman | secretary general = E. F. Hamidy | website = [http://www.koni.or.id koni.or.id] }} The '''National Sports Committee of Indonesia''' ({{lang-id|Komite Olahraga Nasional Indonesia}}, abbreviated '''KONI'''), is the National [[Sport]]s Committee of [[Indonesia]].{{cite web |title=Komite Olahraga Nasional Indonesia |url=http://www.olympic.org/uk/organisation/noc/noc_uk.asp?noc_initials=INA |publisher=[[International Olympic Committee]] |accessdate=2008-06-02}} It was founded in 1946 to unite the various satellite sports associations that was created within the [[Regency (Indonesia)|regencies]]. KONI is responsible on sport development as well as organising sporting events within Indonesian national boundary on national level. Its biggest event is the [[Pekan Olahraga Nasional]] (PON), [[multi-sport event]] held every four years where Indonesian athletes compete. It is the largest sporting event in Indonesia. In 2005, KOI (''Komite Olimpiade Indonesia'' or [[Indonesian Olympic Committee]]) was formed as a separate entity from KONI. KOI is responsible as Indonesian [[National Olympic Committee]], to organise Indonesian participation in international sporting events, such as [[Olympic Games]], [[Asian Games]], [[Southeast Asian Games]], etc. The KONI-KOI separation was based according to ''Undang-Undang Nomor 3 Tahun 2005'' about National Sport System, and further enforced with ''Peraturan Pemerintah Nomor 17 Tahun 2007'' about the organizing of sporting events.{{cite web | title=Sejarah KOI | url=http://www.nocindonesia.or.id/about-us/history.html# | publisher=Komite Olimpiade Indonesia | accessdate=May 17, 2014 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20140110171825/http://www.nocindonesia.or.id/about-us/history.html | archivedate=January 10, 2014 | df=dmy-all }} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Sports governing bodies in Indonesia}} [[Category:National Olympic Committees|Indonesia]] [[Category:Sport in Indonesia]] [[Category:Indonesia at the Olympics]] [[Category:1946 establishments in Indonesia]] [[Category:Sports governing bodies in Indonesia|Sports]] [[Category:Sports organisations established in 1946]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = PLAYPOWER | logo = playpower.png | logo_size = 220px | founded_date = 2008 | location = [[San Diego, California|San Diego]], [[California|CA]] | founder = Derek Lomas, Daniel Rehn, Jeremy Douglass | type = [[Non-profit organization]] [[Computer and video game industry|Video game industry]] | homepage = [http://playpower.org/ http://www.playpower.org] }} [[File:playpower-8bit-logo.png|thumb|Playpower 8-bit logo]] '''PLAYPOWER''' is a 2008 started [[non-profit organization]] designed to create free [[Educational software|educational computer software]] for low income families in [[India]] and other [[developing countries]]. After 2012 the project was reformed as ''Playpower Labs, LLC'' which focuses now on educational games for [[mobile platform]]s.
== Concept == [[File:2009_Bay_Area_Maker_Faire.jpg|thumb|Playpower cheap 8-bit game console, [[Bay Area]] 2008.]] The games are designed to run on [[8-bit]] systems, using designs and [[Central processing unit|processors]] that are in the [[public domain]] e.g. [[Famicom clone]]s which patents have expired,<ref name="about">[http://playpower.pbworks.com/w/page/17230477/About%20the%20$10%20Computer%20and%20Playpower About the $10 Computer and Playpower] by Derek Lomas (2010)</ref> which allows the games to be run on very low cost computers.<ref name = "ppgFebruary102010">[http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/10041/1034643-115.stm Old-style computers get new life in developing countries], [[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]], February 10, 2010</ref> For $12, families can buy a compatible computer with an 8-bit, [[MOS Technology 6502|6502]] [[Microprocessor|processor]], a [[Computer keyboard|keyboard]], a [[Edge connector|slot]] for [[ROM cartridge|game cartridge]]s, a [[mouse (computing)|mouse]], and two [[game controller]]s. Lacking its own monitor, the computer plugs into a TV screen for display.<ref name = "WiredMarch112009">[https://www.wired.com/gadgetlab/2009/03/12-computers-ba/ $12 Computer: Playpower Wants to Save the World 8 Bits at a Time], [[Wired (magazine)|Wired]], March 11, 2009</ref> Part of the software should be acquired as [[source code]] of [[Abandonware|abandoned]] [[educational game]]s, like [[Number Munchers]] and [[Lemonade Stand]], and [[Source port|ported]] by the [[open-source community]].<ref name="about"/><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20100618153809/http://playpowerorg.ning.com/ playpowerorg.ning.com] (archived 2010)</ref>
At least three games were in production as of early 2010, "[[Hanuman]] Typing warrior", "Hanuman's Quiz Adventure" and the "Mosquito game".<ref>[http://web.iiit.ac.in/~harshit.dagaug08/documents/hci_2010.pdf Introducing the “$10 Computer” DESIGN CASE STUDY 1:“HANUMAN, TYPING WARRIOR” Designing Appropriate Educational Games for a $10 Computer in India] by Kishan Patel 1, Ashita Dadlani 2, Manushree Vijayvergiya 3, Aman Jain 3, Harshit Daga 3, Jay Panda 3, Vipul Raheja 3 and Derek Lomas, 1 [[Dhirubhai Ambani Institute of Information and Communication Technology]], 2 Netaji Subhas Institute of Information Technology, 3 International Institute of Information Technology Hyderabad, 4 [[Carnegie Mellon University]], USA</ref> The project [[Open-source software|opened]] the [[source code]] for these three games, written in [[Assembly language|assembly]].<ref>[https://www.hastac.org/blogs/derek-lomas/2010/01/24/games-playpowers-workshop-india Games from Playpower's workshop in India] by James Lomas (on January 24, 2010)</ref> One of them teaches players how to type, which can greatly improve their earning potential in the job market. Another is a multiple choice question game, somewhat similar to that featured in the film ''[[Slumdog Millionaire]]''. And finally, a different game was created to raise awareness of [[malaria]] (which infects 1.5 million people a year in India) by allowing players to kill mosquitoes and accumulate points toward [[antimalarial]] [[mosquito net]]s.<ref name = "ppgFebruary102010"/>
== History == The organization was founded in 2008 by [http://socialmovement.org Derek Lomas] and [http://danielrehn.com Daniel Rehn], who were students at the [[University of California, San Diego|University of California at San Diego]] at the time, and [http://jeremydouglass.com Jeremy Douglass], a [[Postdoctoral researcher|post doctoral]] [[research fellow]] at the same school at the time.<ref name = "WiredMarch112009"/>
In 2012 Daniel Rehn announced on his private homepage the PowerPlay project as "finished".<ref>[http://danielrehn.com/projekt/playpower/ Playpower Foundation (2008–2012)] on danielrehn.com "An open-source community for designing and distributing learning games to ultra-affordable computers in developing regions."</ref>
After 2012 the Playpower project was transformed to "Playpower Labs, LLC" and offers now [[mobile platform]] educational games via Apple's [[Itunes store]] and Google's [[Google Play|play store]].<ref>[https://itunes.apple.com/US/app/id828398560?mt=8 Mathworld] on itunes.apple.com</ref><ref>[https://play.google.com/store/apps/developer?id=Playpower Playpower] on play.google.com</ref>
== Reception == PLAYPOWER won the [[John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation|MacArthur Foundation]]'s Digital Media and Learning Competition in 2009, for which it received $180,000 to help fund its activities. More than 100 volunteer programmers from around the world have signed up to help develop games.<ref name = "ppgFebruary102010"/>
The project was noted broadly<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2009/nov/04/playpower-80s-computing-21st-century playpower-80s-computing-21st-century] on [[theguardian.com]] (2009-11-04)</ref><ref>[http://cn.engadget.com/2009/03/31/8-bit-computer-now-available-for-all-your-homebrewing-needs/ 8-bit-computer-now-available-for-all-your-homebrewing-needs] on [[Engadget]] (April 31, 2009)</ref> in the academic domain<ref>[http://matthewkam.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/CHI20131.pdf "The power of play: design lessons for increasing the lifespan of outdated computers."] by Derek Lomas, Anuj Kumar, Kishan Patel, Dixie Ching, Meera Lakshmanan, Matthew Kam. DOI: 10.1145/2470654.2481379. Conference: Proceedings of the SIGCHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems, aka Proceedings of ACM Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI ’13), Paris, France (April 27-May 2, 2013)</ref><ref>[http://trope-tank.mit.edu/10_PRINT_121114.pdf "10 PRINT CHR$(205.5+RND(1)); : GOTO 10"] [[MIT Press]] book, {{ISBN|9780262305501}}, by Nick Montfort, Patsy Baudoin, John Bell, Ian Bogost, Jeremy Douglass, Mark C. Marino, Michael Mateas, Casey Reas, Mark Sample, and Noah Vawter. "All royalties from the sale of this book are being donated to PLAYPOWER, a nonprofit organization that supports affordable, effective, fun learning games. PLAYPOWER uses a radically affordable TV-computer based on the 6502 processor (the same chip that was used in the Commodore 64) as a platform for learning games in the developing world." (2013)</ref><ref>[http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~mattkam/lab/publications/CSCL2011.pdf "Connecting Computer-Supported Collaborative Learning to Policy and Practice: CSCL2011 Conference Proceedings"] 9th Intl Computer-Supported Collaborative Learning Conf, July 4th-8th, 2011, in Hong Kong. Published as part of, Volume 2, publisher International Society of the Learning Sciences (isls.org), editors Hans Spada / Gerry Stahl / Naomi Miyake / Nancy Law (2011)</ref> and by the web community like [[BoingBoing]].<ref>[http://gadgets.boingboing.net/2009/03/27/the-gaming-computer.html The gaming computer you dreamed of in 1983] by Rob Beschizza on [[BoingBoing]] (Mar 27, 2009)</ref>
==See also== *[[Uzebox]] *[[Humane Informatics]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

{{multiple issues| {{BLP primary sources|date=March 2009}} {{Notability|Biographies|date=March 2009}} }}
'''Richard J. Weibel''' was a magician and noted magic scholar. He was a long-time contributor to [[The Linking Ring]], writing the column, '''Conjuring Psychology''' for many years.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Our Cover: Richard J. Weibel | journal = The Linking Ring | volume = 74 | issue = 9 | pages = 1, 55 | publisher = The International Brotherhood of Magicians | date= September 1994 }} </ref> One of his most notable articles appeared in [[Genii (magazine)|Genii]] magazine in 1980. The article, entitled "Emporiums of Miracles" began a series or articles outlining the history of magic shops throughout the U.S.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Emporiums of Miracles | journal = Genii |date=June 1980}} </ref> Mr. Weibel was featured on the cover of [[The Linking Ring]] in 1994.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Cover | journal = The Linking Ring | volume = 74 | issue = 9 | pages = 1 | publisher = The International Brotherhood of Magicians | date= September 1994 }} </ref> He contributed no less than 1 article to [[The Sphinx]] magazine on the psychology of magic.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Psychology of the Whole | journal = The Sphinx | volume = 50 | issue = 3 | pages = 112 |date=May 1951}} </ref>
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Weibel, Richard J.}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Magicians]]

revision.text:
{{For|the American artist and theorist|Sandy Stone (artist)}} '''Sandy Stone''' is a male character played by Australian comedian [[Barry Humphries]]. Described by [[John Betjeman]] as "this decent man from the suburbs", Stone is one of Humphries' more enduring characters.
The inspiration for Sandy came from a neighbour, a Mr Whittle, whom Humphries knew as a boy, and was portrayed in a short story, ''Sandy Stone's Big Week'', written by Humphries (under the [[pseudonym]] H. Grahame) in 1956 but not published until 1958 (in a Canberra student magazine ''Prometheus''). Humphries describes Sandy, originally called Dusty, as an "elderly, childless man" living in the suburbs of Melbourne. His vocal mannerisms came from an old codger Humphries met on [[Bondi Beach]].<ref>Humphries, B:"My Life as Me", page 234. Penguin Group, 2002</ref>
One of Sandy's monologues was part of the recording ''A Nice Night's Entertainment'', which was particularly enjoyed by Humphries' friend, [[Peter Cook]].<ref>Humphries, B:"My Life as Me", Penguin Group, 2002, p. 170.</ref> Humphries is still writing monologues for Sandy Stone "Australia’s most boring man". He said in 2016 that "slowly the character has deepened, so I begin to understand and appreciate him, and finally feel myself turning into him". He no longer requires makeup for the part, and plays Sandy in his own dressing gown.<ref> "The consummate amateur" by William Cook, ''The Oldie'' [London], September 2016 page 18 </ref>
Sandy's monologues were sometimes inspired by stories recounted to Humphries by friends or family, like the tale of Dot Swift who was handed over to the Twilight Home <ref>Humphries, B:"My Life as Me", page 239. Penguin Group, 2002</ref> which may be the very same home, or perhaps a subsidiary of the one Dame Edna's mother resides in. Barry Humphries sometimes used the character to balance pathos with humor or satire: in one monologue having the ghost of Sandy Stone recall his four-year-old daughter who died in the 1930s and how his wife then suffered a breakdown. The Australian columnist [[Peter Craven (literary critic)|Peter Craven]] commented that Humphries in his Sandy Stone persona could "reduce an audience of young unbelieving cynics to tears with material that might have been written by James Joyce - delivered with wan, uncomprehending wonderment".<ref>Peter Craven, page X "The Spectator Australia 28 July 2012</ref>
The character is featured in the track ''Sandy Agonistes'' on Humphries' comedy recording ''Moonee Ponds Muse, Vol. 1''
The complete scripts (edited by Colin O'Brien) of all the Stone [[soliloquies]] were published in ''The Life and Death of Sandy Stone'' in 1990.
The artist [[Sidney Nolan]] painted a portrait of the character.
== References == {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Stone, Sandy}} [[Category:Comedy characters]] [[Category:Fictional Australian people]] [[Category:Barry Humphries]]

{{Infobox company | name =Silverbird Group | logo = Silverbird Group logo.jpeg | logo_size = 185px | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | logo_padding = | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | trading_name =Silverbird Group | former_name = ''Siverbird Magazine'' | type =[[Privately held company|Private]] | industry = | founded = {{start date|1980}}{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} | founder = [[Ben Murray-Bruce]] | hq_location =[[Victoria Island (Lagos)|Victoria Island]] | hq_location_city =[[Lagos]], [[Lagos State]] | hq_location_country =Nigeria | areas_served = {{flat list | * [[Nigeria]] * [[Kenya]] * [[Ghana]] * [[South Africa]] }} | key_people =[[Ben Murray-Bruce]] (Chairman)
Roy Murray-Bruce | products = | brands = | services =[[Real estate]]
[[Entertainment]] | owner = | website = | homepage = {{URL|www.silverbirdgroup.com}} }} '''The Silverbird Group''' is a Nigerian [[Multinational corporation|multinational]] [[real estate]], [[Media conglomerate|media and entertainment company]] headquartered in [[Lagos]].{{cite web | url=http://www.logbaby.com/directory/silverbird-cinemas-h_15069.html#.Vb6bSevTXBA | title=Silverbird Cinemas Head Quarters | publisher=LogBaby | accessdate=3 August 2015}} The company was established in 1980 by [[Ben Murray-Bruce]] and has gone on to be one of the most popular entertainment companies in Nigeria and beyond.{{cite news | url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2010/10/the-ben-bruce-story/ | title=The Ben Bruce story | work=[[Vanguard (Nigeria)|Vanguard]] | author=Ogbonna Amadi, Entertainment Editor and Lolade Sowoolu | date=30 October 2010 | accessdate=3 August 2015}} The company is the official organizer of [[MBGN]] and [[Mr Nigeria]].{{cite news | url=http://www.thenet.ng/2013/07/photos-meet-the-34-gorgeous-ladies-contesting-for-the-2013-mbgn-crown/ | title=PHOTOS: Meet the 34 gorgeous ladies contesting for the 2013 MBGN crown | work=The Net | author=Abiodun Omigie | accessdate=3 August 2015}} == Siverbird Productions == Siverbird Productions is a division of the company that organizes the [[Most Beautiful Girl in Nigeria]] pageant which began as '''Miss Universe Nigeria''' in 1983 but was later renamed to its present name. This division is also responsible in the organization of the [[Mr Nigeria]] pageant.{{cite news | url=http://www.dailyindependentnig.com/2014/11/mr-nigeria-ladies-always-stalk-bakare/ | title=As Mr. Nigeria, ladies always stalk me –Bakare | work=Daily Independent | author=Ifeoma Ononye | date=1 November 2014 | accessdate=3 August 2015}} ==Silverbird Communications== The Siverbird Communications comprises the company's radio station Rhythm 93.7 FM and Silverbird Television. [[Rhythm 93.7 FM Lagos]] was established in 1997 while Silverbird Television commenced transmission in Lagos in 2003.{{cite news | url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2010/10/the-ben-bruce-story/ | title=The Ben Bruce story | work=[[Vanguard (Nigeria)|Vanguard]] | author=Ogbonna Amadi, Entertainment Editor and Lolade Sowoolu | date=30 October 2010 | accessdate=3 August 2015}} In 2002, [[Rhythm 93.7 FM Port Harcourt]] was established and the Silverbird TV was also set up. ==Silverbird Cinemas== The Silverbird Cinema is one of the biggest cinemas in [[West Africa]] with 69 screens in branches across Nigeria, [[Accra]] and [[Nairobi]].{{cite news | url=http://www.ekoiff.org/2012/11/03/silverbird-group-supports-3rd-eko-international-film-festival/ | title=Silverbird Group Supports 3rd Eko International Film Festival | work=Eko International Film Festival | date=3 November 2012 | accessdate=3 August 2015}}{{cite book|author=Carmela Garritano|title=African Video Movies and Global Desires: A Ghanaian History|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Smqfl7gk3wcC&pg=PA214|date=15 February 2013|publisher=Ohio University Press|isbn=978-0-89680-484-5|pages=214–}} The first cinema was opened in May 2004 at the Silverbird Galleria in Victoria Island, Lagos. Massive commercial success has given rise to the opening of additional multiplexes in different locations across Nigeria. At the moment, Silverbird has cinemas in the following cities in Nigeria: Abuja, Lagos, Uyo, Warri and Port Harcourt.{{Cite web|url=http://silverbirdcinemas.com/about|title=About Silverbird Cinemas. Nigeria's Leading Cinemas Chain|website=silverbirdcinemas.com|access-date=2016-04-09}} ==Silverbird Properties== Silverbird Properties is one of the fastest growing divisions of the company. This division is responsible for all real-estate related activities and it currently operates in [[Bayelsa State]] and [[Akwa Ibom State]].{{cite web | url=http://www.silverbirdgroup.com/properties | title=Silverbird Properties | accessdate=3 August 2015}} ==Silverbird Film Distribution== This division of the company is responsible for all film distribution activities.{{cite news | url=http://www.sunnewsonline.com/new/ramsay-nouah-set-to-shine-as-tempting-fate-hits-cinemas/ | title=Ramsay Nouah set to shine as Tempting Fate hits cinemas | work=[[The Sun (Nigeria)|The Sun]] | date=13 June 2015 | accessdate=3 August 2015}} ===Silverbird Mall=== {{Main|Silverbird Galleria}} The Silverbird Mall is located in [[Victoria Island (Lagos)|Victoria Island]], Lagos.{{cite book|author=Leo Zeilig|title=Class Struggle and Resistance in Africa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vrjbAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA3|year=2009|publisher=Haymarket Books|isbn=978-1-931859-68-4|pages=3–}} It consists of the popular [[Silverbird Galleria]].{{cite web | url=http://www.lagos-nigeria-real-estate-advisor.com/silverbird-cinemas.html | title=Silverbird Cinemas Silverbird galleria Lagos Nigeria | publisher=Lagos-Nigeria-Real-Estate-Advisor | accessdate=3 August 2015}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.silverbirdgroup.com Official Website] * [https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapid=51184811 Silverbird Group on [[Bloomberg Commodity Index|Bloomberg]]] [[Category:1980 establishments in Nigeria]] [[Category:Media companies of Nigeria]] [[Category:Entertainment companies of Nigeria]] [[Category:Film production companies of Nigeria]] [[Category:Companies based in Lagos]] [[Category:Companies established in 1980]] [[Category:Silverbird Group| ]] [[Category:Real estate companies of Nigeria]]

{{Unreferenced stub|date=December 2009}} A '''sound alike''' is a [[person]] who is able to use their [[voice]] to closely resemble that of another person.
In western culture, sound alikes find work as [[impersonator]]s on [[television]] comedy programmes portraying famous individuals.

revision.text:
{{Infobox comic strip | title=Squeak the Mouse |image= Squeak the Mouse.jpg |caption= ''Squeak the Mouse'' #1, featuring the principal characters, Squeak the Mouse and the unnamed cat. |author= [[Massimo Mattioli]] |first= 1980 <ref>Gravett, Paul, "1001 Comics You Must Read Before You Die", Universe, 2012, page 426. </ref> | publisher = [[Catalan Communications]] | genre = [[Black comedy]], [[funny animal]], [[erotic]], [[horror comics|horror]] }}
'''''Squeak the Mouse''''' is an Italian [[black comedy]] [[comic strip]] and later [[comic book]] created by artist [[Massimo Mattioli]]. The comic was set in a fictional [[funny animal]] setting, depicting attempts by its title character, Squeak the Mouse, to outwit a cat who is chasing him. The comic satirizes cartoon series such as ''[[Tom and Jerry]]'', taking the content to extreme levels, which includes [[Graphic violence|gory]] [[horror fiction|horror]] violence and explicit sexual content.
Two issues of a ''Squeak the Mouse'' comic book were produced in 1986 and 1992, the first written from the perspective of the cat, who murders the title character, and the second, written from the perspective of Squeak, who murders the cat. Each issue features a [[zombie]] plotline and a [[pornography|pornographic]] section depicting one of the main characters in an [[orgy]] with several funny animal women.
== Overview == ''Squeak the Mouse'' is a parody of the cartoon series, ''[[Tom and Jerry]]''. Although the style of the drawing is typical of children comics, ''Squeak'' indulges in graphic violent, gore, splatter and pornographic scenes.<ref name=jjj>Domenico Marinelli, "Biblioteca storica: Squeak the Mouse", ''Sbam! Comics'', Vol. 8, April–May 2013, p. 36.</ref>
The first issue of the series is written from the perspective of the cat, who is aggravated by Squeak the Mouse, and ultimately murders the title character. The cat goes to a party and unsuccessfully attempts to have sex with his girlfriend, and instead sleeps with another girl he meets at the party, Squeak the Mouse returns from the dead as a [[zombie]] and murders every one of the guests at the party, until the cat stops the mouse by murdering it with a blender. When the cat returns home, each of the party guests, revived as zombies, attempt to kill him, leading him to kill each of the undead in self-defense. The next day, the cat engages in an [[orgy]] with a number of beautiful women, but Squeak the Mouse returns once more and slaughters each of the women, leading the cat to kill Squeak once more before chasing after another mouse. The end of the issue assures readers that Squeak is really dead and will not return.
The second issue, ''Squeak the Mouse 2'', begins with a duck who revives Squeak from the pages of the first ''Squeak the Mouse'' comic book. Squeak proceeds to read his own comic, and is horrified by his own murder, and decides to track down the cat and murder him. However, when Squeak confronts the cat at a screening of ''[[The Texas Chainsaw Massacre 2]]'', the cat tricks Squeak into feeling sympathy for him, which allows the cat to briefly escape before being murdered by the mouse. As Squeak boards a plane heading to a tropical island, the cat returns as a zombie and crashes the plane, killing all of the passengers except Squeak, who escapes, and swims to the nearest island, where a pair of women awaken him by performing [[oral sex]] on Squeak, leading to another orgy sequence. The cat turns up on the island and slaughters the women, and Squeak destroys the cat, leaving only its separated bones, which are found by a [[horror film]]-loving child, who brings the remains home and reassembles them. The skeleton cat slaughters the child and his family, and once again goes after Squeak, who finally gets rid of the cat for good, but decides to antagonize another cat.
== Publication history == The comic was first published in the underground comics magazine ''[[Frigidaire (magazine)|Frigidaire]]'' starting from 1982. The stories were later collected in an eponymous volume in 1984; initially intended to be an ended series, it had a sequel (''Squeak the Mouse 2'') published in 1992.<ref name=jjj/>
== Controversy == On August 1, 1985, New York harbor officials confiscated the comic publication on the grounds that it was pornographic, but a court later overturned that decision.<ref>{{cite book|last=M. Keith Booker|title=Encyclopedia of Comic Books and Graphic Novels|publisher=ABC-CLIO, 2010|isbn=0313357471|page=240}}</ref><ref name="DAK35">{{cite news | last = Sweeney | first = Bruce | date = August 1986 | title = Bernd Metz | work = [[Comics Interview]] | issue = 35 | pages = 38–45 | publisher = [[Fictioneer Books]]}}</ref> According to Bernd Metz of [[Catalan Communications]], the book's USA publisher, ''Squeak the Mouse'' was ruled not obscene "because it failed the third test of the law... the [[Miller test]] as it's called... in that it did not exceed the community standards."<ref name="DAK35"/>
== Legacy == The comics are considered to be an apparent inspiration for [[Matt Groening]]'s ''[[The Itchy & Scratchy Show]]''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Sergio Algozzino|title=Tutt'a un tratto. Una storia della linea nel fumetto|publisher=Tunué, 2005|isbn=8889613068|pages=112–113}}</ref><ref>''[[The Comics Journal]]'', Issues 280-283, Comics Journal Incorporated, 2007, p.27.</ref><ref>Giuseppe Pollicelli (28 August 2011), "Massimo Mattioli: il Disney del porno-horror", ''[[Libero (newspaper)|Libero]]''.</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Costanza Ognibeni|title=Incontro con Massimo Mattioli|url=http://www.cinemartmagazine.it/2010/10/08/incontro-con-massimo-mattioli/|accessdate=23 April 2013|newspaper=CinemArt Magazine|date=8 October 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131220175352/http://www.cinemartmagazine.it/2010/10/08/incontro-con-massimo-mattioli/|archivedate=20 December 2013|df=}}</ref> == See also == * ''[[The Itchy & Scratchy Show]]'' * ''[[Fritz the Cat]]'' * ''[[Happy Tree Friends]]'' * ''[[South Park]]'' * ''[[Tom and Jerry]]''
== References == {{Reflist}}

{{refimprove|date=March 2017}} '''Stuart Cumberland''' (1857–1922) was an English [[Mentalism|mentalist]] known for his demonstrations of "thought reading".
Cumberland was famous for performing [[blindfold]]ed feats such as identifying a hidden object in a room that a person had picked out or asking someone to imagine a murder scene and then attempt to read the subject's thoughts and identify the victim and re-enact the crime. Cumberland claimed to possess no genuine psychic ability and his thought reading performances could only be demonstrated by holding the hand of his subject to read their muscular movements. He came into dispute with psychical researchers associated with the [[Society for Psychical Research]] who were searching for genuine cases of [[telepathy]]. Cumberland argued that both telepathy and communication with the dead were impossible and that the mind of man can not be read through telepathy, only by [[muscle reading]].<ref>Nicola Bown, Carolyn Burdett, Pamela Thurschwell. (2004). ''The Victorian Supernatural''. Cambridge University Press. pp. 87-108. {{ISBN|0-521-81015-9}}</ref>
An opponent of [[spiritualism]], Cumberland would attribute all mediumship phenomena to muscle reading and trickery.<ref>Barry Wiley. (2012). ''The Thought Reader Craze: Victorian Science at the Enchanted Boundary''. McFarland. pp. 102-106. {{ISBN|978-0-7864-6470-8}}</ref>
==Publications== *''A Thought Reader's Thoughts'' (1888) *''People I Have Read'' (1905) *''That Other World'' (1918) *''Spiritualism: The Inside Truth'' (1919)
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{magic-stub}} {{entertainer-stub}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cumberland, Stuart}} [[Category:1857 births]] [[Category:1922 deaths]] [[Category:English magicians]] [[Category:Mentalists]]

'''Taliesin Williams''' (bardic name '''Taliesin ab Iolo''' or '''Ab Iolo'''; 9 July 1787 – 16 February 1847) was a [[Welsh people|Welsh]] poet and author, and son of notable [[Literary forgery|literary forger]] [[Iolo Morganwg]].<ref name="Merthyr-Tydfil.)1903">{{cite book|author=Charles Wilkins (of Merthyr-Tydfil.)|title=The history of the iron, steel, tinplate and ... other trades of Wales: with descriptive sketches of the land and the people during the great industrial era under review|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yJQ1AQAAIAAJ|accessdate=15 October 2012|year=1903|publisher=Joseph Williams}}</ref>
He was born in [[Cardiff]], went to school in [[Cowbridge]], and became an assistant teacher at a [[boarding school]] run by Reverend David Davies in [[Neath]]. He gradually took over leading the proceedings of regional [[Gorsedd]]au from 1814, when he was awarded the title of [[Neo-Druidism|Druid]]. He worked as a [[stonemason]] with his father in 1815. In 1816 he opened a school in [[Merthyr Tydfil]], where he worked as a schoolmaster until the end of his life. He assisted with the publication of his father's work ''Cyfrinach Beirdd Ynys Prydain'' ("Mystery of the bards of the island of Britain") in 1829.
In 1834 he won the [[Chairing of the Bard|bardic chair]] at the [[Cardiff Eisteddfod]] with an [[awdl]] entitled ''Y Derwyddon'' (The [[Druid]]s). In 1838 he won the [[Crowning of the Bard|bardic crown]] at the [[Abergavenny Eisteddfod]] for an essay on the [[Coelbren y Beirdd]] (the alleged bardic alphabet) which was published in 1840.<ref>Williams, Taliesin., (ab Iolo), Coelbren Y Beirdd; a Welsh Essay on the Bardic Alphabet, W. Rees, Llandovery, 1840.</ref>
On his father's death he was left his father's archive of manuscripts, which he believed were all genuine. After much work compiling and editing 26 volumes,<ref name="Waring1850">{{cite book|author=Elijah Waring|title=Recollections and anecdotes of Edward Williams the bard of Glamorgan; or, Iolo Morganwg|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0OIIAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA4|accessdate=15 October 2012|year=1850|publisher=Charles Gilpin|pages=4–}}</ref> a selection was published in 1848 under the title of the [[Iolo Manuscripts]] by the [[Welsh Manuscripts Society]].<ref name="MorganwgJones1848">{{cite book|author1=Iolo Morganwg|author2=Owen Jones|author3=Society for the Publication of Ancient Welsh Manuscripts, Abergavenny|title=Iolo manuscripts: A selection of ancient Welsh manuscripts, in prose and verse, from the collection made by the late Edward Williams, Iolo Morganwg, for the purpose of forming a continuation of the Myfyrian archaiology; and subsequently proposed as materials for a new history of Wales|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6jREAAAAIAAJ&pg=PP1|accessdate=15 October 2012|year=1848|publisher=W. Rees; sold by Longman and co., London|pages=1–}}</ref> Much of Taliesin's work was based on that of his father.
After his death in 1847 he was succeeded as [[Archdruid]] by Evan Davies ([[Myfyr Morganwg]]).
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{Art UK bio}} * [http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/en/328/ The Abergavenny Eisteddfod, National Museum Wales] * [http://www.iolomorganwg.wales.ac.uk/pobl-taliesinwilliams.php Taliesin Williams (1787-1847), Project at the Centre for Advanced Welsh and Celtic Studies, University of Wales] * [http://yba.llgc.org.uk/en/s-WILL-TAL-1787.html WILLIAMS , TALIESIN ( Taliesin ab Iolo ; 1787 - 1847 )] * [http://wbo.llgc.org.uk/en/s-DAVI-EVA-1801.html Welsh Biography Online - DAVIES , EVAN ( Myfyr Morganwg ; 1801 - 1888 )]
{{Authority control}}

[[Viki (website)|Viki]]{{cite web|title=The Lost Tomb - 盜墓筆記 |url=http://www.viki.com/tv/25731c-the-lost-tomb|website=Viki|accessdate=2015-04-15}} |picture_format = |audio_format = |first_run = |first_aired ={{Start date|2015|6|12|df=y}} |last_aired = |preceded_by = |followed_by = |related = ''[[The Mystic Nine]]''
''[[Time Raiders]]'' |website = |budget = ¥500 million |production_website = http://weibo.com/u/3292078391 }} '''''The Lost Tomb''''' ({{zh|s=盗墓笔记|t=|p=Dàomù Bǐjì}}) is a 2015 Chinese [[web series]] based on the internet novel ''[[Daomu Biji]]''. The series will have 8 seasons filmed over a period of 8 years.{{cite web|title=Li Yi Feng signs 8-year contract for The Lost Tomb|url=http://www.avirtualvoyage.net/2014/07/li-yi-feng-signs-8-year-contract-for-the-lost-tomb.html|website=A Virtual Voyage|accessdate=}} The first season premiered on [[iQiyi]] on 12 June 2015.{{cite web|url=http://media.people.com.cn/n/2015/2/c40606-27144287.html|title=《盗墓笔记》今晚首播 李易峰“地下探秘”压力大|work=People's Daily|language=zh}} ==Synopsis== Wu Xie ([[Li Yifeng]]) is an antique shop owner who comes from a family of tomb raiders. As he continues the family trade with his team of tomb raiders, he finds lost treasures of the [[Warring States period|Warring States]] as well as the answers to the tragedies of his family's past. With the help of his grandfather's notes and his team – the quiet Zhang Qiling ([[Yang Yang (actor)|Yang Yang]]), the resourceful Pang Zi (Liu Tianzuo), the experienced Wu Sanxing ([[Ken Chang]]), San Xing's loyal helper Pan Zi ([[:zh:魏巍 (演員)|Wei Wei]]), and the skillful Ah Ning ([[Tiffany Tang]]) – Wu Xie sets out to find the lost treasures as well as the people responsible for the massacre of his family. ==Cast== ===Main=== {|class="wikitable " width="70%" |- style="background:cornflowerblue; color:white" align=center |style="width:12%"|'''Actor'''||style="width:10%"|'''Role'''||style="width:30%"|'''Introduction''' |- |
[[Li Yifeng]]
||
Wu Xie
{{small|(Wú Xié; 吴邪)}}
|| Owner of an antique store in [[Hangzhou]], [[China]]. He finds a map to an ancient tomb in an ancient scroll from the Warring States one day which leads him to seek out the tomb in the map. Wu Xie is an innocent and naive character who is loyal to his friends. He is also the descendant of the 5th Master of the Mystic Nine. {{cite web|script-title=zh:《盗墓笔记》起底角色 李易峰领护宝分队|url=http://ent.sina.com.cn/v/m/2015-01-09/doc-icczmvun4835091.shtml|website=Sina|accessdate=2015-04-15|language=zh}} |- |
[[Yang Yang (actor)|Yang Yang]]
||
Kylin / Xiaoge
{{small|(Zhāng Qǐlíng; 张起灵 / Little Master)}}
|| A mysterious character whose rarely speaks and always seems to be in a daze. He is often hired as an assistant to many grave-robbing endeavors and is highly competent at it; very little is known about him, even his real name. |- |
[[Tiffany Tang]]
||
A'ning
{{small|(Ā'níng; 阿宁)}}
|| A grave-robber and the first major female introduced in the series, her motives are unclear but seems to be working against the protagonists. |- |
Liu Tianzuo
||
Fatty / Pangzi
{{small|(Wáng Pàngzi; 王胖子)}}
||Nicknamed "Gold Getting Xiao Wei", he is a northern grave-robber (as opposed to Wu Xie, from the south) and teams up with both Wu and Zhang throughout the story; together they are referred to as the "Iron Triangle." |- |
[[Ken Chang]]
||
Wu Sanxing / Third Uncle
{{small|(Wú Sānxǐng; 吴三省)}}
|| Wu Xie's third uncle, has a keen interest in tombs and antiques. He joins the group to locate the tomb under the request of his nephew, Wu Xie. |- |
Wei Wei
||
Pan Zi
{{small|(Pān Zi; 潘子)}}
|| Wu Sanxing's assistant. Sansheng's right-hand man, who had served in the Vietnam War prior to becoming a grave-robber. |} ===Supporting=== {|class="wikitable " width="70%" |- style="background:cornflowerblue; color:white" align=center |style="width:12%"|'''Actor'''||style="width:10%"|'''Role'''||style="width:30%"|'''Introduction''' |- | Li Chenhao || Master High || Wu Xie's friend, an overseas returnee who is an expert at advanced technology. |- | Sun Yaoqi || Chen Chengcheng || Sangdekao's subordinate. She disguises herself as the niece of Chen Wenjin to get close to Wu Xie. |- | [[Cheng Pei-pei]] || Huo Xiangu ||One of the members of mystic nine clan. |- | [[Ying Er]] || Huo Xiuxiu || Huo Xiangu's granddaughter. |- | Li Xinliang || Liu Tai|| |- | Zhang Xiaochen || Jie Yuchen|| |- | Lu Xingyu || Minister Lu || |- | Su Qing || Yao Guang || |- | Huang Ming || King Lushang|| |} ==Production== In June 2014, a press conference was held at Shanghai and attended by representatives of H&R Century Pictures, Beijing Enlight Media and Nanpai Investment. It was announced that a film, television series and online game would be adapted from the novel ''[[Daomu Biji]]'' by Nanpai Sanshu.{{cite web|url=http://www.chinanews.com/yl/2014/06-13/6278361.shtml|title=《盗墓笔记》将拍电视剧 网友力荐原作者出演|work=People's Daily|language=zh}} In particular, the television series would be divided into 8 seasons filmed over a period of 8 years.{{cite web|url=http://ent.qq.com/a/20140721/065113.htm|title=李易峰出演《盗墓笔记》 卖身八年坦言很值得|work=Tencent|language=zh}} The series is directed by Cheang Pou-soi who directed the 2014 film ''[[The Monkey King (film)|The Monkey King]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.chinanews.com/yl/2014/06-13/6279672.shtml|title=剧版《盗墓笔记》海报曝光 场面宏大|work=China News|language=zh}} Other notable production crew included [[Hong Kong Film Award]]-winners Angie Lam and Bill Lui.{{cite web|url=http://ent.sina.com.cn/v/m/2014-12-02/doc-iawzunex4881364.shtml|title=《盗墓笔记》杀青 铁三角合影片场搞怪|work=Sina|language=zh}} Chun Hung Mak, who worked on the ''[[Chinese Paladin]]'' series, composed the soundtrack of the series. [[Principal photography]] commenced in August 2014 and wrapped up on 30 November 2014 at [[Yamdrok Lake]], [[Tibet]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ctibet.cn/culture/detail/CUL429863672864.html|title=《盗墓笔记》日前西藏杀青 将以羊湖美景开场|work=ctibet.cn|language=zh}} Location filming took place at the Beijing Farm Animal Research Center and the Dagao International Art Unit.{{cite web|url=http://ent.ifeng.com/a/20140822/40261575_0.shtml|title= 网曝李易峰《盗墓》片场照 中科院动物所热拍|work=ent.ifeng.com|language=zh}} ===Casting=== On June 24, 2014, [[Li Yifeng]] confirmed through [[Sina Weibo|Weibo]] that he would be taking on the leading role of Wu Xie.{{cite web|url=http://ent.sina.com.cn/v/m/2014-06-26/11004165241.shtml|title=李易峰《盗墓》演吴邪 张起灵将选85后|work=Sina|language=zh}} On August 31, 2014, official posters of the main cast including Li, Yang Yang, Liu Tianzuo, Ken Chang and Wei Wei were released.{{cite web|url=http://news.sina.com.tw/article/20140831/13246768.html|title=《盜墓筆記》人物海報 五大角色整裝出發|work=Sina|language=zh}} On November 5, 2014, [[Tiffany Tang]] was revealed to be the female lead of the series.{{cite web|url=http://ent.sina.com.cn/v/m/2014-11-05/10564235764.shtml|title=《盗墓笔记》再曝海报 唐嫣饰演阿宁|work=Sina|language=zh}} ==Deviation from novel== In the novel, Wu Xie is the owner of an antique store but in the series, he is an overseas returnee who studied at a German University and returned to China to return an antique to the country. The rest of the team also became "protectors of the antique" instead of a "tomb-raiding team".{{cite web|url=http://news.jsnol.com/a/2015/0613/6505.html|title=《盗墓笔记》首播遭吐槽 网友：确定不是护宝笔记？|work=news.jsnol.com|language=zh}} Two new characters, High Master and Cheng Chengcheng were also created for the web series. ==Reception== ''The Lost Tomb'' is the most watched web drama of 2015 with over 2.8 billion views.{{cite web|url=http://ent.people.com.cn/n1/2016/0204/c1012-28110580.html|title=《上网看剧成时尚 《盗墓笔记》荣登2015网剧王|publisher=People's Daily|language=zh}} Despite its popularity, the series was criticized for its draggy story-line and poorly done special effects. Fans of the novel also commented that the plot and characters deviated too much from the original novel.{{cite web|url=http://news.singtao.ca/toronto/2015-06-21/entertainment1434862090d5644124.html|title=《盜墓筆記》情節顛覆 特效劣質唐嫣李易峰新劇遭差評|work=news.singtao.ca|language=zh}}{{cite web|url=http://culture.people.com.cn/BIG5/n/2015/0626/c87423-27210924.html|title=人民日報刊文評《盜墓筆記》：收視率雖高吐槽不少|work=People's Daily|language=zh}} ==Awards and nominations== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Award !! Category !! Recipient !! Result |- | 2014 ||
2015 [[IQiyi|iQiyi]] All-Star Carnival{{Cite web|url=http://t.m.youth.cn/transfer/index/url/www.youth.cn/preview/news.youth.cn/yl/201412/t20141208_6195468.htm|title="尖叫2015爱奇艺之夜"年度榜单重磅出炉|website=Youth.cn|access-date=2016-12-16}}

|| Best Web Series|| {{won}} |- |} ==See also== *''[[Time Raiders]]'', a 2016 film based on the same novel series *''[[The Mystic Nine]]'', a 2016 prequel on the same novel series ==International broadcast== {| class="sortable wikitable" ! {{Infobox company | name = Throwback Entertainment | logo = | caption = | type = [[Video game]]s | foundation = 2006 | location = [[Toronto, Ontario]], [[Canada]] | key_people = Thomas Maduri {{small|(Chairman)}}
Robert Maduri {{small|(President)}} | industry = [[Video game industry]] | products = ''[[Vexx]]''
''[[Extreme-G]]''
''[[Gladiator: Sword of Vengeance]]'' | revenue = | num_employees = 25–50 | homepage = {{Official website|http://www.throwbackentertainment.com}} }} '''Throwback Entertainment''' is a [[video game developer]] from [[Toronto, Ontario]], [[Canada]]. Throwback Entertainment has developed over 190 games, totaling over 200 million copies sold. ==History== In 2006, Throwback announced the purchase of the Acclaim library, consisting of over 190 titles such as ''[[Iggy's Reckin' Balls]]'', ''[[Extreme-G]]'', ''[[Gladiator: Sword of Vengeance]]'' and ''[[Vexx]]''.{{Cite web | url = http://throwbackentertainment.com/throwback-entertainment-completes-largest-title-acquisition-in-video-game-history/ | title = Throwback announces Acclaim library acquisition | author = Throwback Entertainment | publisher = ''Throwback Entertainment'' | date = 2006-07-07 | accessdate = 2015-09-15 }} On February 2011, WeGo Interactive Co., Ltd., located in Seoul, Korea, purchased the ''[[Re-Volt]]'' franchise from Throwback Entertainment.http://throwbackentertainment.com/?p=327 On May 6, 2015, during [[Microsoft]]'s IGNITE conference, it was announced that ''Gladiator: Sword of Vengeance'' will be made available on Xbox One and the Windows stores.{{Cite web | url = http://throwbackentertainment.com/?p=1292 | title = Throwback Entertainment Unleashes ‘Gladiator: Sword of Vengeance’ on the World of Windows | date = 2015-05-06 | accessdate = 2015-05-07 }} On December 29, 2015, Throwback released ''[[TrickStyle]]'' on [[GOG.com]]. In 2016, Throwback released iOS 10 sticker packs for ''Gladiator: Sword of Vengeance'', ''TrickStyle'', ''Legends of Wrestling'', ''Wrestling'', ''SX Superstar'' and ''All-Star Baseball'' on the iMessage App Store.{{cn|date=August 2018}} On December 20, 2016, Throwback released ''Gladiator: Sword of Vengeance'' on the l Windows Store. ''Gladiator: Sword of Vengeance'' was also subsequently released on Steam on January 28, 2017. Both versions included enhanced HD rendering and full controller support. On February 21, 2017, ''TrickStyle'' was released on the Steam store along with the soundtrack as free DLC. On May 2, 2017, ''[[Extreme-G 2]]'' was added to Steam. On September 1, 2017, Throwback with Jordan Freeman Group released ''[[TrickStyle]]'' on ZOOM Platform with exclusive Mac support.https://www.zoom-platform.com/#news--exclusive-release-trickstyle-with-mac-support ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official website}} *[http://xbox.ign.com/articles/717/717265p1.html IGN: Acclaim Games Live On] *[http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/throwback-picks-up-multiple-acclaim-titles GamesIndustry.biz: Throwback picks up multiple Acclaim Titles] [[Category:Video game companies of Canada]] [[Category:Companies based in Toronto]] [[Category:Video game publishers]]

revision.text:
'''Truly Indie''' is an "innovative distribution program" providing [[independent film]]makers the sales and marketing tools necessary to distribute their films by-passing traditional distribution companies. By providing a way for self-funded distribution, Truly Indie aims to enable filmmakers to "retain control" over all rights and decisions relating to their films. The program was launched by [[Mark Cuban]] and [[Todd Wagner]]'s media company [[2929 Entertainment]] in 2005 in [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], [[Texas]].
==Business model == Truly Indie enables theatrical distribution funded by filmmakers themselves, mainly through 2929 Entertainment's Landmark Theaters. The filmmaker pays an up front fee that covers all distribution costs (marketing, advertising, and publicity). Securing a one-week run in at least five markets, the filmmaker keeps all of box office receipts and retains all rights to their film.<ref>[http://www.indiewire.com/biz/2005/10/cuban_and_wagne.html Cuban & Wagner Unveil Truly Indie, New Initiative Featuring Filmmaker Funded Theatrical Releases] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070301190005/http://www.indiewire.com/biz/2005/10/cuban_and_wagne.html |date=2007-03-01 }} Interview 2005-10-17</ref><ref>[http://diyfilmmaker.blogspot.com/2006/11/doug-block-51-birch-street-truly-indie.html Doug Block, 51 Birch Street, Truly Indie: The Interview] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160611020151/http://diyfilmmaker.blogspot.com/2006/11/doug-block-51-birch-street-truly-indie.html |date=2016-06-11 }} 2006-11-12</ref>
==Filmography - Distributor == [[Independent film]]s distributed by Truly Indie as of 2007: *''[[The Prisoner or: How I Planned to Kill Tony Blair]]'' (2007) *''[[Maxed Out: Hard Times, Easy Credit and the Era of Predatory Lenders]]'' (2006) (dist. 2007) *''[[51 Birch Street]]'' (2005) *''[[Beowulf & Grendel]]'' (2005) *''[[Fall to Grace (2005 film)|Fall to Grace]]'' (2005) *''[[Cavite (film)|Cavite]]'' (2005) *''[[Automne]]'' (2004) *''[[The Dogwalker]]'' (2002) *''[[Tibet: A Buddhist Trilogy]]'' (1979)
==Sources == <references/> *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061231032449/http://www.trulyindie.com/contact_us.html Truly Indie] official site *[http://2929productions.com/Index.cfm?FuseAction=Page&PageID=1000039&ArticleID=59 The launch of Truly Indie]{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Press release *{{imdb company|0179468}} *[http://www.the-numbers.com/market/Distributors/TrulyIndie.php Box Office Performance for Truly Indie] at [http://www.the-numbers.com/ The Numbers]
[[Category:2005 establishments in Texas]] [[Category:Film distributors of the United States]] [[Category:Independent films]] [[Category:Entertainment companies of the United States]] [[Category:Companies established in 2005]]
{{US-film-company-stub}}
